metadata.title: Osteomyelitis
anatomical location body part affected: Skeleton/commonly, long bones of the limbs and the vertebrae
description: Osteomyelitis is an infection, usually bacterial, of bone. It is characterized by inflammation, progressive necrosis and destruction, and sequestra (i.e., segments of necrotic bone separated from living bone by granulation tissue). The infection may involve the periosteum, cortex, and metaphysis, as well as surrounding soft tissue(1,14)
In the acute stage, medical therapy is guided by the results of surgical debridement and bone cultures(1,2)

Antibiotic treatment usually resolves uncomplicated cases of focal osteomyelitis in about 4 to 6 weeks, without recurrence. Recalcitrant cases may require hyperbaric medicine, limb salvage, or amputation(2,3)

Infected fracture or surgical prothesis, vascular insufficiency, diabetes, neuropathy, and compromised immunity are associated with chronic osteomyelitis and amputation. In such cases, aggressive surgery (bone stabilization/reconstruction and muscle flap coverage) is required to improve the functional outcome(3,4)

Patients with resolved osteomyelitis may present for rehabilitation services with impairments that reduce physical functioning(1) –Restricted movement of the involved extremity or spine –Reduced ability to bear weight –Pain/tenderness of involved site –Motor/sensory deficits

contraindications precautions to test: Consult physician immediately if unresolved or worsening osteomyelitis is suspected

causes:: Bacterial infection, often in immunocompromised persons(1,14)–Hematogenous (bloodborne) osteomyelitis is usually monomicrobial or identified by a dominant microbe(1,14)-Staphylococcus aureus  (present alone or in combination with other bloodborne microbes)(3)-Pseudomonas aeruginosa  (present in 20–27%  of cases)(3)-Nontuberculous mycobacteria (e.g., Mycobacterium marinum )-Multidrug-resistant  bacteria (e.g., methicillin-resistant  Staphylococcus aureus [MRSA])-Enterobacteriaceae (e.g., Salmonella  organisms, especially in sickle cell disease)-Streptococcus pyogenes-Enterococcus-Coagulase-negative  staphylococci–Contiguous or exogenous (direct contact inoculation) osteomyelitis is commonly a polymicrobial infection(1,14)–Secondary fungal infection may occur
Although a rare occurrence, osteomyelitis can be caused by herpes zoster in patients with an immunocompromisedsystem(12)
pathogenesis: Osteomyelitis is classified as either contiguous/exogenous or hematogenous–Contiguous/exogenous – bacteria are directly inoculated into the bone at time of trauma, during surgical reduction andinternal fixation of fractures, or from an adjacent skin and soft-tissue  infection (e.g., decubitus ulcer)–Hematogenous – bloodborne bacteria reach the bone from a remote point of entry. For example, spontaneousosteomyelitis can occur in children, possibly due to metaphyseal capillary loops, which allow microbesto multiplyisolated from the immune system(9)

Osteomyelitis in children is primarily hematogenous, although it can also occur secondary to penetrating trauma, surgery,or infection in a contiguous site(16)–“Goalkeeper’s hip” is when a soccer goalkeeper develops osteomyelitis secondary to the impact of the iliac crest with theground. Authors of a case report also report an instance of “goalkeeper’s hip” during kickboxing. The patient received akick in the flank, and from this blunt trauma it was determined he developed osteomyelitis(16)
Most cases of adult osteomyelitis are a result of skin penetration to the bone below(9)
Vertebral osteomyelitis is usually a hematogenous infection of vertebral body; often involves neurologic complications(motor/sensory deficits)(1)
Osteomyelitis can also be classified based on the portion of the bone affected, physiological status of the host, and riskfactors(14)

Chronic osteomyelitis: cases with nonhealing ulcer or draining sinus due to recurrent inflammation; accompanied bycontinuing low-grade fever and pain–All classes of osteomyelitis can progress to chronic stage
risk factors ,: Trauma/injury to bone (especially open fracture) or skin
Postoperative infection after joint or bone surgery (e.g., internal fixation of a fracture, amputation, arthroplasty)

overall contraindications precautions: Notify physician immediately if patient presents with systemic symptoms such as abrupt onset of fever, lethargy/malaise, or irritability(1,14)
Increasing pain and episodes of severe night pain should be referred to physician(6)
Consult with physician if soft tissue defects show signs of active infection
Confirm weight-bearing,  activity, and immobilization restrictions with physician
Presentation will vary based on phase of rehabilitation and time since onset
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Patients may report an insidious onset or may have experienced a recent trauma or surgery. What symptoms is the patient experiencing (include systemic and local)? Where are the localized symptoms occurring? Does the patient have any other illness/infection, or has the patient recently had one (e.g., respiratory or urinary tract infection)? Have there been any complications? What has been the patient’s course of rehabilitation up to this point?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Antibiotic therapy Surgery (e.g., surgical debridement, amputation, joint fusion) may be necessary. Goals of surgery include adequate debridement, obtaining appropriate microbiology specimens, dead space management, and achieving skeletal stability with soft tissue cover(17) Debridement alone without adequate deadspace management is suboptimal in managing chronic osteomyelitis(17) Different approaches are available for dead space management, although there is no clear evidence that one is superior to the other (i.e., biological versus nonbiological)(17) Lipoharvest is a novel method for bone defects secondary to osteomyelitis. Authors of a case study report successfully treating a 26year-old female with chronic osteomyelitis. It is an alternative to traditional autologous bone graftingthat uses fat as a deadspace  filler, however more studies are recommended on this method(18) There is limited evidence regarding adjunctive therapies such as hyperbaric oxygen therapy and negative pressure wound therapy. However, hyperbaric oxygen therapy used in combination with antibiotics and/or surgical debridement has been associated with high recovery rates(13) Authors of a systematic review of the literature on the effectiveness of hyperbaric oxygen therapy in conjunction with antibiotic treatment and surgical debridement foundthat the available evidence may support a beneficial role of adjunctive hyperbaric oxygen, especially in refractory cases of chronic osteomyelitis(19)
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Antibiotics are used in almost all cases to assist in the eradication of infection (see Causes ). The antibiotics are often selected based on the sensitivity testing performed on needle biopsy and wound swab cultures to identify those that will have the greatest efficacy. These antibiotics are often given intravenously, often for 46 weeks(14) Authors of a 2013 Cochrane systematic review of antibiotic treatment of chronic osteomyelitis concluded that the route of antibiotic administration (oral versus parenteral) does not affect the rate of disease remission if the causative bacterial species is susceptible to the antibiotic used(8) There was insufficient evidence to determine the best antibiotic to use or optimal length of treatment Patients with neuropathic forefoot osteomyelitis show similar outcomes when comparing antibiotic therapy and surgical management in terms of healing rates, time of healing, and shortterm  complications(10) Is the patient’s pain adequately controlled?
diagnostic tests completed: Clinically, the most useful studies are plain radiographs, MRI, and technetium-99m  bone scintigraphy.For plain radiographs it may take up to 14 days after the infection begins for findings to appear. MRI can detect infection earlier
(35days of disease onset), but is often limited to cases that involve surgical hardware(15)
The gold standard for diagnosis of osteomyelitis is histopathologicexamination of bone specimens coupled with bone culture(20)
Negative uptake results on white blood cell single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) are a good marker for diagnosing diabetic foot osteomyelitis(11)

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there any activities or positions that aggravate or alleviate the patient’s symptoms?
history of present illness.body chart: Use a body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document the nature of symptoms (constant vs intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Systemic signs of infection Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe ______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Does the patient have diabetes mellitus, sickle cell disease, or other predisposing factors? Has he or she had a joint replacement? Is there a history of osteomyelitis? Has the patient had any other recent surgeries, fractures, or injuries?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient use I.V . drugs? Does the patient smoke? Does the patient plan to return to work, sport, or recreational activities?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom the patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: If applicable, assess the current ambulatory assistive device for proper fit and use; or evaluate for suitable ambulatory assistive device, as indicated. Assess for proper fit of and determine the need for additional supportive/protective equipment, footwear, bracing, or orthotics
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess for balance reactions, which may be altered due to immobilization, weight-bearing  restrictions, weakness, or the presence of external fixators. Assess static and dynamic standing balance within the limits of weight-bearing restriction
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess for palpable distal pulses, especially in patients with suspected vascular insufficiency (i.e., diabetes mellitus)Assess ability to maintain proper posture and body mechanics with functional mobility; this is especially important for patients with spinal involvement (e.g., log rolling with bed mobility)
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess mobility within limits of weight-bearing  status, including ability in bed mobility, transfers (if applicable), and stair climbing. Utilize functional independence measure (FIM) for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait within limits of weight-bearing  status and need for assistive devices. Assess ability to maintain prescribed weight-bearing  precautions. Assess walking ability, including tandem gait, turns, and walking on toes, and presence of gait deviations (without ambulatory assistive device). Note for shortened step length on the unaffected side secondary to decreased ability to bear weight on the affected side. The Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) can be used for objective measurement of safetyAssess involved joint mechanics and flexibility. Postpone ligament stress testing until physician’s guidelines permitIf spine is involved or if neuropathy is present, assess tone and motor control as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: In patients with extremity involvement, assess proximal and distal muscle strength, and compare to contralateral extremity strength. Confirm that the patient has adequate strength to adhere to weight-bearing  restrictions, perform appropriate transfer and gait patterns, and use appropriate assistive devices
observation inspection palpation includi: Localized edema, erythema, and warmth may be present. Assess initially for presence of these symptoms and continue to monitor for symptom progression in patients undergoing antibiotic treatment

Assess for intact sutures following surgical intervention, drainage from incisions or wounds, erythema, warmth, and other signs of infection. Assess size, length, width, and depth of wounds or ulcerations and integrity of tissue in and surrounding the ulcerations or wounds. Identify which wound care products will be used if wound care will be part of the physical therapy plan of care
Assess for pain with weight-bearing,  at rest, and with palpation of the affected area

Assess tenderness (V AS) at the affected area. Palpate and inspect the area for tenderness, soft tissue breakdown, and drainage from any wound or ulceration that is present. Observe for signs of infection
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess overall posture for inability to bear weight through the affected extremity, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess for ROM and flexibility deficits once the infection is resolved and wound healing has occurred
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Screening should be done to identify deficits secondary to comorbidities (e.g., diabetes) or if the spine is involved. Light touch, protective sensation, temperature discrimination, proprioception, and other sensations may all be impaired in patients at risk for osteomyelitis (diabetic neuropathy)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –Health-related  quality of life questionnaire such as Health Survey Short Form-36  (SF-36) –Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) when lower extremity affected –Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure when upper extremity affected

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Osteomyelitis causing deficits in physical functioning, including reduced strength, ROM, balance, gait, and functional mobility; wound care Rule out  (14,15) Charcot arthropathy, especially in persons with diabetes  SAPHO syndrome (synovitis, acne, pustulosis, hyperostosis, and osteitis) Arthritis including rheumatoid arthritis Metastatic bone disease Fracture, including pathological and stress fractures Gout Avascular necrosis of the bone Bursitis Sickle cell vaso-occlusive  pain crisis Systemic infection from other source Aseptic bone infarction
prognosis: The management of osteomyelitis can result in a large financial burden for patients due to the multiple surgeries, prolonged hospital stays, and extensive courses of antibiotics that are often required(17)

The prognosis of acute osteomyelitis is good with aggressive antimicrobial and surgical therapy (response rates range 90–100%).(14)Reinfection can occur. In adults the recurrence rate of chronic osteomyelitis is about 30% at 12 months. Morbidity is increased in cases involving prosthetic devices(15)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Physician for specific red flags of infection or inability to achieve functional goals because of persisting pain; nursing/wound care clinic for nonhealing wounds
treatment summary: Research on physical therapy for patients with osteomyelitis is lacking
In resolved cases, exercise therapy may be indicated to improve ROM, strength, and functional mobility
Therapists may participate in wound care (e.g., dressing changes, debridement), as ordered by the physician

Patients should be educated on the prolonged nature of therapy and the need for compliance with treatment recommendations to ensure adequate wound healing, thereby reducing the risk for recurrence(15) . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Gait, balance, and functional mobility impairments resulting from immobilization and weight-bearing restrictionsImprove gait, balance, and functional mobility while ensuring the patient maintains immobilization and weight-bearing restrictions through use of appropriate assistive devices and gait patternsGait training _ Patients should be educated and trained in the use of appropriate assistive devices (walker, crutches). This training will also include instruction and practice in appropriate gait patterns to maintain weight- bearing restrictions _ _ Stair training with appropriate patterns and assistive devices should also be included for patients who need to navigate stairs to enter/ exit their homeBalance activities _ Standing balance activities may be utilized to increase static and dynamic balance. These may be conducted in single- limb stance or sitting if the patient is non- weight-bearing on the involved extremity. Appropriate guarding and gait belt should be utilized, as indicated _ _ Reaching, catching, balloon tapping, and manual resistance activities may be used. _ Gradual resumption of participation in athletic activities may occur after antibiotic treatment(6)A home exercise program to complement the physical therapy exercise program should be progressed as the patient moves through phases of healing  Decreased strength and ROMImproved strength and ROMStrengthening exercises _ Seated strengthening exercises for the proximal musculature may be utilized to assist in maintaining non- weight-bearing status while standing and ambulating for patients with lower extremity involvement _ Progressive strengthening exercises using cuff weights, resistance bands, or manual resistance _ _ Lower extremity strength may be addressed using a comprehensive global strengthening program. Standing exercises may be used as appropriate, with sufficient support provided by assistive device (walker) or parallel bars _ _ Observe weight- bearing restrictions, immobilization, and any other restrictions per physician orders. _ Upper extremity weakness can be addressed with free weights, resistance bands, or manual resisted exercises to improve the use of assistive devices and allow the patient to adhere more easily to weight-bearing restrictions of the lower extremity. _ Core strengthening for patients with spinal involvementProgress based on the individual patient needs; consider the patient’s age, physical impairments, and cognitionPatients may perform a global strengthening program of the unaffected areas as appropriate and within the limitations of physician restrictions to prevent muscle strength loss and facilitate increased ease of ambulation  Unhealed wound(s) Healed wound(s) Wound care _ In some cases, therapists may be expected to perform dressing changes, apply topical antibiotic or other medications, perform dull or sharp debridement, and provide management of a “wound vac” systemN/A Instruction in signs of localized/systemic infection and wound care, as appropriate .

healed wound s: Wound assessment – measure length, width, depth
Visual inspection of size and color of wound
Observe for any abnormal drainage, abnormal redness/swelling
functional rom, strength, and mobility o: Manual muscle test (MMT), goniometric measurements, DASH outcome measure, LEFS
improved balance: Berg Balance scale, Tinetti Balance Assessment Tool

maintenance or prevention: The patient should avoid exacerbating activities and activities that may impede healing, such as tobacco use and contamination of open incisions or wounds
Patients at risk for infection due to vascular insufficiency should closely monitor any cuts or scrapes
Medical treatment should be obtained if surrounding soft tissue shows signs of infection
Patients with neuropathy or diabetes should inspect their feet and other desensitized areas daily to identify any injury or ulceration
Glycemic control for patients with diabetes
Open wounds should be covered and well protected to prevent further contamination and introduction of bacteria
Animal bites should be treated with antibiotics(15)
Timely diagnosis and treatment of primary infections to avoid seeding of bone
